text: how much does this mean to you it means
a lot it really means a lot i wouldn't
have throw my hat in the ring if it
hadn't been for me I think the pinnacle
of anything I've ever done is my sport
is what drives me and fires me I'm very
lucky at one of those people that wakes
up most days knowing since the age of 11
that in one way or another athletics was
going to shape my day and when I mean
announced that he wasn't going to stand
again for the term that ended just well
ends on august 31st I thought this is
what I want to do you know it's a great
honored you no doubt that we elected a
very strong team today and sit a lot
alongside those guys men and women and
and really sort of shape the future the
sport that's a it's a massive honour
great challenge with a massive on you've
won Olympic gold you've organized a home
Olympics how does this compare I think
this for me is is is the biggest thing
that I've undertaken I said in my few
words to the Congress trying to capture
in five minutes 50 years of life in a
sport was quite a challenge but the one
point I really did want to make was that
you know that it is my sport that drives
me that it is the number one Olympic
sport and that we really want to do
everything we possibly can to make sure
that it is in the best possible shape
and that means attracting more young
people it means finding new sponsors it
means sort of looking at reshaping the
calendar a little bit making sure that
people understand what the season means
all these things are going to be
fantastic challenges what's your number
one priority I think making sure that
the organization really does function
across 214 now 216 Federation's and
therein lies you know the strength but
also the challenge you know we are
probably the most global of sports to
more countries joins us this morning
South Sudan Kosovo but making sure that
the sport does not move ahead at very
speed and bearing in mind that we
we have OCR Nia 20 different countries
territories islands and we're sort of
trying to figure that out at the same
time as harnessing the power houses of
track and field in Jamaica and the
United States and Russia and China and
and therein therein lies the challenge
so making sure that those Federation's
are properly financed to deliver the
sport that we know and they know as they
told us they want to deliver and to do
it in a way that recognizes their need
not necessarily what we think they must
be doing sitting it at the center as you
know the election happened against a
backdrop of allegations of systematic
doping and a cover-up in effect by those
the top of the sport how confident are
you that your proposals are better
resourced and independent Doping agency
can regain trust of all those are two
propositions that don't accept yes there
are challenges yes there you know we you
know we live in the world of doping in
sport my sport has led the way on that
and it's it has its it has it's clear
challenges and you know I'm not naive
and coy about that but nor would I
remotely accept that at the highest
level of the testing processes within
the i ee f that we have been sort of
asleep on the job we've led from the
front on this and we have a very proud
record and i will always defend the
quality of our teams in monaco that have
been dealing with that but the the
proposition that i put forward about an
independent doping anti-doping system is
simply that you know at the heart of the
sport a sports it's trust and integrity
and if there is a real problem or a
perceived problem we have to deal with
it and actually perceptions are very
very serious and we need to make sure
that they're cut there is not a remote
place for anybody to go in terms of
those perceptions you receive some
criticism for describing some of those
accusations as a declaration of war i
double AF said it was sensationalist to
some extent do you stand by that or do
you have any regrets about
the language used no I don't have any
regrets about the language I used you
know as I said again to the Federation's
this morning you know they they know in
recent weeks I am in their corner their
fight is my fight and I will always
defend the probity and integrity of my
sport because I've been in it far too
long and other people that are in it I
sit alongside them and they are people
that have a zero tolerance to drugs in
sport particularly in track and field
and I think we have a very proud record
on what we've achieved in that we have
actually led the way it's not to say
there aren't challenges out there of
course we know there are but actually
the the thought that we somehow have
been sitting on our hands or being
complicit in something is just is just
inaccurate one last question said if I
may say we're three days away from the
flagship event the World Championships
inevitably there'll be a some degree of
suspicion hanging over this event given
what we've been told and what we've read
in recent times what would your message
be to the sporting public that was
around the world watching these
championships maybe watching justin
gatlin win for example a two-time drugs
cheat behind 100 meters what would you
message me to those who won't perhaps
believe what they see anymore well they
should and the vast majority of athletes
that are coming to these championships
do it to the very highest standards of
integrity it's you know it's it's the
bedrock of our sport and they espouse
those values in an extraordinary way and
every now and again you will get a few
that choose to step beyond those that
framework those rules that's the same in
any organization our responsibility is
actually not just to weed out the cheat
it is to protect the rights of the of
the clean athletes to compete openly
unfairly and have the trust of the
public that come in and watch them that
has of course to be always our number
one priority
